critique: This document establishes a board to investigate a labor dispute between a railway company and its employees. It aims to prevent interruption of interstate commerce. There's no clear indication of ideological tilt, immigration stance, or impact on civil liberties. It seems to expand executive power slightly by creating the board, but this is within the bounds of the Railway Labor Act. It doesn't directly address federalism or social inclusion. It leans towards economic intervention by preventing changes to the conditions out of which the disputes arose.
